The premise of the nursery being the demise seems like a stretch. Most coastal sharks today have nurseries, and they seem to be fine. As the shark gets larger it moves into the next nursery where it can eat and still be sheltered by the coast. Furthermore, a baby meg would be the size of many of the other sharks in the area, so it would seem that they would be able to feed and grow just as the smaller adult sharks do.  They just adapt their food to where they are in the food chain, like many animals today do.  I dont like linking the nursery to their extinction, I'm more of a the adults were having problems adapting to a changing climate kinda guy. Thanks for the channel, and the info. This one is a little to speculative for me though!

I'm sorry but I see some weaknesses. Sharks cycle through teeth and have plenty of teeth per mouth. You can't just crunch numbers to figure the number of different sharks in an area. All teeth aren't uniform in size or quality. Plus sharks of varying sizes would scramble data. You could analyze DNA if it survived that long, but what would that tell ya? Carbon dating has some flaws in it. We know the half life but you can't assume the point of decay the atom was in when the being passed and so you don't have a date to back track to.
